Article.Abstract: Crystal structures of the class II major histocompatibilty complex (MHC) protein, HLA-DR1, generally show a tight fit between MHC and bound peptide except in the P6/P7 region of the peptide-binding site. In this region, there is a shallow water-filled pocket underneath the peptide and between the pockets that accommodate the P6 and P7 side chains. We investigated the properties of this pocket with the idea of engineering substitutions into the corresponding region of peptide antigens to increase their binding affinity for HLA-DR1. We investigated d-amino acids and N-alkyl modifications at both the P6 and P7 positions of the peptide and found that binding of peptides to HLA-DR1 could be increased by incorporating an N-methyl substitution at position 7 of the peptide. The crystal structure of HLA-DR1 bound to a peptide containing a P7 N-methyl alanine was determined. The N-methyl group orients in the P6/P7 pocket, displacing one of the waters usually bound in this pocket. The structure shows that the substitution does not alter the conformation of the bound peptide, which adopts the usual polyproline type II helix. An antigenic peptide carrying the N-methyl modification is taken up by antigen-presenting cells and loaded onto endogenous class II MHC molecules for presentation, and the resultant MHC-peptide complexes activate antigen-specific T-cells. These results suggest a possible strategy for increasing the affinity of weakly immunogenic peptides that might be applicable to the development of vaccines and diagnostic reagents.
Article.ArticleTitle: Exploration of the P6/P7 region of the peptide-binding site of the human class II major histocompatability complex protein HLA-DR1.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Alanine(analogs & derivatives; analysis); Amino Acid Sequence; Binding Sites; Crystallization; HLA-DR1 Antigen(chemistry; genetics; metabolism); Humans; Hydrogen Bonding; Lymphocyte Activation; Methylation; Models, Molecular; Molecular Structure; Peptides(chemistry; immunology; metabolism); Protein Conformation; Protein Structure, Secondary; Sarcosine(analysis); Structure-Activity Relationship; T-Lymphocytes(immunology)

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: The epitope is an analog of the HA(308-316) peptide. It has the following mutations: Y308 -> F308, T313 -> A313, L314 -> (METH)A314, K315 -> A315.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The crystal structure contains the MHC/epitope complex bound to the superantigen (SAG) staphylococcal enterotoxin type C-3 variant 3B2 (SEC3-3B2). SAG PDB chain is D. This variant contains the following mutations: K43->S43, L45->45F, A46->46K, H47->47W. The SAG molecule was used as an aid to crystallization of the MHC/epitope complex. The epitope is an analog of the HA(308-316) peptide. It has the following mutations: Y308 -> F308, T313 -> A313, L314 -> (METH)A314, K315 -> A315. The first mutation was done to reduce the relative importance of the P1 pocket binding while maintaining the original binding frame. Also, In order to prevent ionization of the epitope termini that might disrupt the conserved hydrogen-bonding network that binds the peptide in the binding site, the N-terminus of the peptide was acetylated (ACET(M1)) and the C-terminus was amidated (AMID(L9)).

ThreeDimensionalStructureOfComplex.Comments: [| P1: F1; P2: V2; P3: K3; P4: Q4; P5: N5; P6: A6, P7: (MAA)7; P8: A8; P9: L9; |] The SAG molecule interacts with the MHC outside of the peptide binding groove, on the flanking helix from the Î±-subunit. Comparison between the structure of the complexes HLA-DR1/HA/SEC3-3B2 with HLA-DR1/TPI(23-37)/SEC3-3B2 [PDB: 1KLU] showed the following. The important difference between these two complexes is in the P6/P7 area, with the inclusion of an N-methyl group in residue P7: (MAA)7; of the first structure. Because of this methylation, one of the four water molecules found in the second structure is displaced. As such, the hydrogen bonding network in the area rearranges so that instead of the hydrogen bonds the displaced water molecule was making, namely two hydrogen bonds between two water molecules and one water mediated hydrogen bond between B:E28 and P7: (MAA)7; , now there is an additional hydrogen bond to the carbonyl oxygen of the P7: (MAA)7; backbone. No other significant conformational changes were observed.

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Substitution at position P6 or P7 with any of 19 D-amino acids did not significantly affect binding to HLA-DR1, except Pro at P7 significantly increased binding. The peptide was acetylated at the N-terminus and amidated at the C-terminus.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: The epitope contains N-methyl glycine at the P7 position.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Peptides containing additional substituents on the amide nitrogen of the P7 residue were evaluated their binding to HLA-DR1. The substituents included linear and branched aliphatic chains designed to identify whether the P6/P7 pocket would be able to accommodate groups larger than methyl and linear aliphatic amines designed to be complementary to the generally acidic electrostratic character of the P6/P7 region. None of the N-alkyl substitutions (ethyl, IC50 = 3000; isopropyl, IC50 = 3100; aminoethyl, IC50 = 19000; aminopropyl, IC50 = 31000; and aminobutyl, IC50 = 9600) increased the binding affinity over that observed for the N-methyl substitution, suggesting that larger is not necessarily better in the P6/P7 pocket.

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: A mouse T-cell hybridoma was transfected with a chimeric T-cell receptor carrying human variable alpha and beta domains from the well characterized HLA-DR1-restricted Ha-peptide-specific human T-cell clone HA1.7 and murine constant domains. Generation of the T cell clone HA1.7 was previously described in the reference cited: Lamb and Fledmann (1982) Nature 300: 456â458 [PMID: 6216411].

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Epitope-specific HA1.7 T cell hybridoma responded to immobilized epitope/HLA-DR1 complexes or to the epitope presented by fixed or live HLA-DR1 B cells. The T cell hybridoma responded equally well to the epitope with N-methyl leucine at position 9.

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: The epitope contains N-methyl leucine at position 9.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope contains N-methyl leucine at position 9 which binds in the P6/7 pocket.
